prompt: <description>**Part 1: Three-dimensional rectangular prism with a hollow center** Begin by creating a new coordinate system with euler angles of 0.0, 0.0, 0.0 and a translation vector of [0.0, 0.0, 0.75]. This will be the base for our first CAD part. Now, let's create the 2D sketch for this part. We'll be drawing on face_1 of the coordinate system. Start with line_1, move from point [0.0, 0.0] to point [0.75, 0.0]. Then, proceed with line_2 from [0.75, 0.0] to [0.75, 0.75]. Follow it up with line_3 from [0.75, 0.75] to [0.0, 0.75], and finally, line_4 from [0.0, 0.75] back to the starting point [0.0, 0.0]. We now have a closed loop with four lines. Next, we need to scale the sketch using a scaling parameter of 0.75. After scaling, transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the euler angles and translation vector provided in the coordinate system. To generate the 3D model, extrude the 2D sketch by a depth of 0.75 units towards the opposite direction of the normals. With this, we have successfully constructed a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a hollow center, featuring a flat top and bottom. **Part 2: CAD model of a rectangular prism with a smaller rectangular prism on top** Create a new coordinate system with euler angles of 0.0, 0.0, 0.0 and a translation vector of [0.0001, 0.0021, 0.75]. This is the base for our second CAD part. We will first create the 2D sketch for this part on face_1 of the coordinate system. Draw line_1 from point [0.0, 0.4478] to point [0.3, 0.7478]; line_2 from [0.3, 0.7478] to [0.0, 0.7478]; and line_3 from [0.0, 0.7478] back to the starting point [0.0, 0.4478]. We now have a rectangular prism shape in 2D. Repeat the same steps for face_2. Draw line_1 from point [0.4519, 0.0] to point [0.7519, 0.0]; line_2 from [0.7519, 0.0] to [0.7519, 0.3]; and line_3 from [0.7519, 0.3] back to the starting point [0.4519, 0.0]. Scale the sketch using a scaling parameter of 0.7519, and transform it into a 3D sketch using the coordinates provided. This time, when extruding, use a depth of 0.6 units towards the opposite direction of normals, and perform a cut feature operation to remove this volume and create a smaller rectangular prism on top of the larger one. With this, you have constructed a CAD model of a rectangular prism with a smaller rectangular prism on top.</description>

<description>**Part 1: Three-dimensional rectangular prism with a hollow center** Begin by creating a new coordinate system with euler angles of 0.0, 0.0, 0.0 and a translation vector of [0.0, 0.0, 0.75]. This will be the base for our first CAD part. Now, let's create the 2D sketch for this part. We'll be drawing on face_1 of the coordinate system. Start with line_1, move from point [0.0, 0.0] to point [0.75, 0.0]. Then, proceed with line_2 from [0.75, 0.0] to [0.75, 0.75]. Follow it up with line_3 from [0.75, 0.75] to [0.0, 0.75], and finally, line_4 from [0.0, 0.75] back to the starting point [0.0, 0.0]. We now have a closed loop with four lines. Next, we need to scale the sketch using a scaling parameter of 0.75. After scaling, transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the euler angles and translation vector provided in the coordinate system. To generate the 3D model, extrude the 2D sketch by a depth of 0.75 units towards the opposite direction of the normals. **Part 2: CAD model of a rectangular prism with a smaller rectangular prism on top** Create a new coordinate system with euler angles of 0.0, 0.0, 0.0 and a translation vector of [0.0001, 0.0021, 0.75]. This is the base for our second CAD part. We will first create the 2D sketch for this part on face_1 of the coordinate system. Draw line_1 from point [0.0, 0.4478] to point [0.3, 0.7478]; line_2 from [0.3, 0.7478] to [0.0, 0.7478]; and line_3 from [0.0, 0.7478] back to the starting point [0.0, 0.4478]. We now have a rectangular prism shape in 2D. Repeat the same steps for face_2. Draw line_1 from point [0.4519, 0.0] to point [0.7519, 0.0]; line_2 from [0.7519, 0.0] to [0.7519, 0.3]; and line_3 from [0.7519, 0.3] back to the starting point [0.4519, 0.0]. Scale the sketch using a scaling parameter of 0.7519, and transform it into a 3D sketch using the coordinates provided. This time, when extruding, use a depth of 0.6 units towards the opposite direction of normals, and perform a cut feature operation to remove this volume and create a smaller rectangular prism on top of the larger one.</description>
